person.note: Yin(2) Zhu [7104] Cai's [4126] uncle, Yuan's [4129] brother. Zhu's ancestors lived for generations in Taiyuan without producing any illustrious personages. His grandfather, Wenhua [4128], was the first to earn a civil service degree. When Wenhua buried his father, Yi, in Henan, the lineage moved there. Zhu Gou's [7405] father. His grandnephew, the neo-Confucian scholar Yin(2) Shun [4125], lost his wife and only surviving son when the Jurchen took Luoyang. Shun was buried in Shaoxing, Kuaiji xian. Shun had studied under Cheng(1) Yi [3105]. One of Shun's son-in-laws, Cheng(1) Wei [3111], was either Cheng(1) Yi or Cheng(1) Hao's [3102] grandson. One possibility is that another son-in-law, Xing(1) Chun [3371], was a son of Xing(1) Shu [7106], who had also studied with Cheng(1) Yi. Lu(9) Jizhong [1293] was Shun's menren. Yin(2) Zhu was Zhang(1) Shi's husband, Fu(6) Zhiqing's [7226] grandfather-in-law, and the father-in-law of Zhang(1) Jingxian [205] (twice, sororate) and Xie(1) Jingping [7240]. He recommended Di(1) Qing [8127] to Han(1) Qi [630]. Han Qi, WJ,47.1a-7b; Ouyang Xiu, WJ, 28.6a-7b; Yin Zhu, WJ, 23.9a, 28.15a; Yin Shun, WJ, p. 24. CBD, 1, 93-94.
